head.title: Methanol Tolerant Pt–C Core–Shell Cathode Catalyst for Direct Methanol Fuel Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Methanol Tolerant Pt–C Core–Shell Cathode Catalyst for Direct Methanol Fuel Cells

Methanol crossover is one of the largest problems in direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). Methanol passing from the anode to the cathode through the membrane is oxidized at the cathode, degrading the DMFC performance, and the intermediates of the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) cause cathode catalyst poisoning. Therefore, it is essential to develop a cathode catalyst capable of inhibiting MOR while promoting the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), which is a typical cathode reaction in DMFCs. In this study, a carbon-encapsulated Pt cathode catalyst was synthesized for this purpose. The catalyst was simply synthesized by heat treatment of Pt–aniline complex-coated carbon nanofibers. The carbon shell of the catalyst was effective in inhibiting methanol from accessing the Pt core, and this effect became more prominent as the graphitization degree of the carbon shell increased. Meanwhile, the carbon shell allowed O2 to permeate regardless of the graphitization degree, enabling the Pt core to participate in ORR. The synthesized catalyst showed higher performance and stability in single-cell tests under various conditions compared to commercial Pt/C.

div.p:
Methanol crossover is one of the largest problems in direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). Methanol passing from the anode to the cathode through the membrane is oxidized at the cathode, degrading the DMFC performance, and the intermediates of the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) cause cathode catalyst poisoning. Therefore, it is essential to develop a cathode catalyst capable of inhibiting MOR while promoting the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), which is a typical cathode reaction in DMFCs. In this study, a carbon-encapsulated Pt cathode catalyst was synthesized for this purpose. The catalyst was simply synthesized by heat treatment of Pt–aniline complex-coated carbon nanofibers. The carbon shell of the catalyst was effective in inhibiting methanol from accessing the Pt core, and this effect became more prominent as the graphitization degree of the carbon shell increased. Meanwhile, the carbon shell allowed O
2
to permeate regardless of the graphitization degree, enabling the Pt core to participate in ORR. The synthesized catalyst showed higher performance and stability in single-cell tests under various conditions compared to commercial Pt/C.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) is considered one of the promising energy systems in the future because of its easy fuel storage, high energy density, and environmental friendliness alongside a proton exchange membrane fuel cell that uses hydrogen as fuel instead of methanol.
(1,2)
However, the sluggish kinetics of methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) and methanol crossover in DMFC have prevented its widespread use. Many researchers have investigated anode catalysts to improve the kinetics of MOR, and Pt–Ru alloys have proven to be the most promising anode catalyst.
(3−6)
However, the methanol crossover problem has not been solved yet, and various studies are currently underway. Methanol crossover is a phenomenon in which methanol crosses from the anode to the cathode through the membrane due to the methanol concentration gradient, hydraulic pressure gradient, and electro-osmotic drag by proton transport.
(7)
During DMFC operation, methanol, crossing over from the anode to the cathode, is chemically oxidized with oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode, causing a mixed potential. This reduces the cell voltage and lowers the power output. The cathode catalyst poisoning by reaction intermediates of MOR also occurs, leading to the catalyst deactivation. The methanol crossover greatly degrades DMFC performance.

Since the methanol crossover accounts for 50% of the cell performance losses, it is essential to prevent methanol crossover or avoid the formation of a mixed potential at the cathode for DMFC development.
(2,8)
There are several common approaches to overcome this problem. The most straightforward way is to introduce a thick membrane that can retard the methanol crossover. However, the high proton transport resistance of a thick membrane, such as Nafion 115 membrane, is bound to degrade cell performance. Other approaches, such as lowering the methanol concentration and increasing the platinum catalyst loading at the cathode, are also effective in mitigating the methanol crossover problem. However, these approaches are negative for cell performance and cost either.

Alloy catalysts with resistance to methanol and high activity toward ORR are another alternative to the methanol crossover problem. Pt- and Pd-based alloy catalysts with transition metals are major attempts to improve catalytic activity for ORR in the presence of methanol. For instance, PtPdCo/C, PtCr/C,
[email protected]
/C, PdM(M = Co, Ni, Cr)/C, and PdFe/C catalyst were employed as cathode catalysts and exhibited improved methanol resistance and ORR activity in DMFCs.
(9−14)
For example, the methanol resistance of the Pt-Pd alloy catalyst originates from the Pd atom that changes the active site structure to be inert to MOR. The Pd atom causes the three Pt active sites not to be adjacent, rendering the catalyst inactive to MOR—three adjacent Pt active sites are essential for MOR.
(15−17)
However, these catalysts still suffer from transition metal dissolution and only a few catalysts were successfully applied to DMFCs. The low stability of methanol-tolerant alloy catalysts is another challenge for DMFCs. Recently, cathode catalysts based on nonprecious metals, such as Fe-N-C with high ORR activity and high methanol resistance, have also been studied.
(18−21)

In hydrogen fuel cells, attempts have been made to protect the metal dissolution by surrounding the Pt cathode catalyst with a thin layer of carbon. A porous or graphitized carbon layer protects Pt nanoparticles from aggregation and dissolution by inhibiting Pt ion transport through the layer, while passing oxygen (O
2
) which is the ORR reactant.
(22−26)
Cheng et al. reported that the carbon layer has different oxygen permeability depending on its thickness and thus, the carbon layer thickness should be precisely controlled to less than 1 nm in order to enable ORR on the Pt catalyst.
(22)
Tong et al. showed basic experimental results that methanol-tolerant Pt cathode catalysts for DMFCs could also be prepared using the carbon layer capable of blocking methanol transport in the same manner.
(23)

In DMFCs, the carbon layer protects the cathode catalyst from two major degradation pathways, metal dissolution and MOR. Thus, the use of a carbon layer with selective permeability is substantially effective in a cathode catalyst for a DMFC. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are few studies related to this strategy. In this study, a methanol-tolerant Pt cathode catalyst was synthesized by encapsulating individual Pt nanoparticles into a well-controlled carbon layer. We provided the experimental evidence that the carbon shell selectively allowed oxygen to permeate but not methanol. The carbon encapsulation greatly improved the stability of monometallic Pt catalysts, which were the cathode of DMFCs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The carbon-encapsulated Pt catalysts on carbon nanofibers (
[email protected]
/CNF) were synthesized using a Pt–aniline complex as a precursor, which was previously reported by our group.
(27)
H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O (120 mg) was dissolved in 35 mL of aniline monomer solution by sonication for 5 min. The solution was then stirred at room temperature for 5 h to form precipitates, Pt–aniline complexes. The Pt–aniline complexes were separated from the solution by centrifugation and mixed with an aqueous solution of 0.2 M HCl to remove excess aniline. The Pt–aniline complexes were then filtered and dried at 80 °C in a vacuum oven. Fifty milligrams of the dried Pt–aniline complexes were mixed with 50 mg of CNFs in 30 mL of ethanol. The ethanol was then evaporated at 60 °C, resulting in the CNFs coated with Pt aniline complexes. The coated CNFs were heat-treated at 600, 700, and 900 °C for an hour under a N
2
atmosphere. The prepared catalysts were named
[email protected]
/CNF600,
[email protected]
/CNF700, and
[email protected]
/CNF900, where the numbers indicated the heat treatment temperature.

The crystal structures of the catalysts were identified using an X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (XRD; Smart Lab, Rigaku, Japan). XRD patterns were obtained at a rate of 3° s
–1
at two-theta of 20–80°. The morphologies of the catalysts were observed using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM; Talos F200X, FEI, USA) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under an O
2
atmosphere using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA N-1000/1500, SCINCO, Republic of Korea) to investigate the graphitization degree of carbon shells (heating rate: 3 °C min
–1
). An X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS; PHI 5000 Versa Probe II, ULVAC-PHI, Japan) was used to investigate the surface chemical state of the catalysts.

A three-electrode electrochemical cell was used for the measurements. The working electrode was a glassy carbon rotating disk electrode (GC RDE) with a geometric area of 0.196 cm
2
. An Ag/AgCl (3.5 M KCl) electrode and Pt coil served as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. All measured potentials were converted based on the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The catalyst ink slurry was prepared by mixing 10 mg of
[email protected]
/CNF, 66 μL of ionomer (5 wt % Nafion solution, Dupont, USA), and 1 mL of ethanol. The catalyst was then loaded on GC RDE by dropping the catalyst ink. The Pt loading amount was 150 μg
Pt
cm
–2
. The commercial Pt/C (20 wt %, Johnson Matthey, USA) was used for the reference. The methanol tolerance of the catalyst was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in an Ar-saturated aqueous electrolyte containing 1 M methanol and 0.1 M HClO
4
. The potential was scanned from 0.05 to 1.2 V at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
. Chronoamperometry (CA) was also performed to investigate the methanol penetration through the carbon layer. The measurement was initiated with an applied potential of 0.55 V in an Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
. After 500 s of measurement, O
2
gas was injected into the electrolyte instead of Ar gas to cause ORR. Methanol was then injected at 1500 s, resulting in total concentrations of 1, 2, 3, and 5 M. ORR and MOR on the catalyst were competitively induced by the methanol injection. The working electrode was rotated at 1600 rpm during the measurement. All catalysts were activated by potential cycling prior to CV and CA. The potential was cycled from 0.05 to 1.2 V at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
for 10 cycles in Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
.

A membrane electrode assembly (MEA) was prepared using a catalyst-coated membrane method. The catalyst inks for the anode and cathode was sprayed onto a 127 μm-thick membrane (Nafion 115, Dupont, USA) to load 2.0 mg
PtRu
cm
–2
and 0.3 mg
Pt
cm
–2
for the anode and cathode, respectively. For the anode, the catalyst ink was prepared by mixing 56.1 mg of PtRu black (Pt:Ru = 50:50, Alfa Aesar, USA), 128 μL of ionomer, 561 μL of deionized water, and 2.805 mL of ethanol. The cathode catalyst ink was composed of 6.2 mg of
[email protected]
/CNF, 43 μL of ionomer, and 625 μL of ethanol. The catalyst-coated membrane on both sides was then sandwiched between two gas diffusion layers with (Sigracet 39 BC, SGL Carbon, Germany) and without a microporous layer (TGP-H-060, Toray, Japan) for each of the anode and cathode. The performance of the MEA was evaluated at 70 °C using a fuel cell test station (CNL-SPPS, CNL Energy, Republic of Korea); a single cell polarization curve was obtained by increasing the current density by 0.04 A cm
–2
every 10 s. During the test, methanol (3 mL min
–1
) and unhumidified air (200 sccm) were fed to the anode and cathode, respectively. The active area of the MEA was 5 cm
2
. The MEA was activated by CV cycling before the test. The voltage was cycled between 0.05 and 1.2 V at a scan rate of 0.1 V s
–1
for 150 cycles while feeding H
2
(75 sccm) and N
2
(200 sccm) to the anode and cathode, respectively. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed at 0.4 V in the frequency range of 100–0.1 kHz, and the amplitude of the sinusoidal modulation voltage was 10 mV. Impedance spectra were recorded at the same conditions as single-cell operation.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a–c shows TEM images of
[email protected]
/CNFs heat-treated at different temperatures. Pt nanoparticles showed uniform dispersion on the CNF surface regardless of the heat treatment temperature. The average diameter of Pt nanoparticles was 2.8 (±0.8) nm, 3.3 (±0.7) nm, and 3.8 (±0.9) nm for
[email protected]
/CNF600,
[email protected]
/CNF700, and
[email protected]
/CNF900, respectively. With increasing heat treatment temperature, the size of Pt nanoparticles increased slightly but did not show a significant change. This indirectly indicates that the carbon shell covering each Pt nanoparticle effectively protected the aggregation of Pt nanoparticles during heat treatment. The carbon shell was clearly observed in the magnified HR-TEM image of
[email protected]
/CNF900 (
Figure
1
d). Each Pt nanoparticle was covered with several layers of carbon. The carbon shells of
[email protected]
/CNF600 and
[email protected]
/CNF700 were also observed, as shown in
Figure S1
. The elemental mapping images of
[email protected]
/CNFs in
Figure S2
show that N and Pt were distributed in the same position, which supports that Pt nanoparticles and carbon shells were both derived from Pt–aniline complexes upon heat treatment.
(27)
Figure
1
e shows the XRD patterns of
[email protected]
/CNFs. The diffraction peaks of Pt(111), Pt(200), and Pt(220) were clearly observed regardless of the heat treatment temperature, indicating that the Pt nanoparticles were polycrystalline. TGA was also used to indirectly confirm the presence of the carbon shell.
Figure
1
f shows TGA profiles of
[email protected]
/CNFs under an O
2
atmosphere. There were two distinct stages of weight loss. At temperatures of 227–332 °C, the first weight-loss stage was associated with the decomposition of lowly graphitized carbon shells containing N atoms. This decomposition was delayed as
[email protected]
/CNF was heat-treated at higher temperatures, indicating that the graphitization degree of carbon shells increased as the heat treatment temperature increased.
(23,28)
This corresponds well with the
I
D
/
I
G
ratio results obtained from the Raman spectra (
Figure S3 and Table S1
). As the heat treatment temperature increased, the
I
D
/
I
G
ratio decreased, also indicating that the graphitization degree of the carbon shell covering each Pt nanoparticle increased.
(29)
The decomposition of highly graphitized carbon, CNFs, occurred in the second weight-loss stage in the temperature range of 400–550 °C. The residuals after TGA, assumed to be Pt, were 28.9, 30.5, and 30.8 wt % for
[email protected]
/CNF600,
[email protected]
/CNF700, and
[email protected]
/CNF900, respectively.

div.p:
Figure 1. HR-TEM images of (a)
[email protected]
/CNF600, (b)
[email protected]
/CNF700, (c)
[email protected]
/CNF900, and (d)
[email protected]
/CNF900 in high magnification and their (e) XRD patterns and (f) TGA profiles. Insets in (a–c) show Pt nanoparticle size distributions of
[email protected]
/CNFs. The white arrows indicate the carbon shells covering the Pt nanoparticles.

div.div:
Pt 4f and N 1 s XPS spectra of
[email protected]
/CNFs are shown in
Figure S4
. The chemical state of Pt hardly changed with the heat treatment temperature. In N 1 s XPS spectra of
[email protected]
/CNFs, four types of N peaks were observed, pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, pyridinic N
+
–O
–
, and graphitic N. These peaks are generally observed in N-doped carbon materials.
(30,31)
Figures S2 and S4
demonstrate that Pt nanoparticles were covered with N-doped carbon shells that originated from the decomposition of aniline.
Table
1
lists the elemental composition of
[email protected]
/CNFs that were obtained by XPS. As the heat treatment temperature increased, the N content decreased from 6.60 to 3.96 at%. This is because the higher the graphitization degree, the lower the N content.
(31)
N atoms are incorporated into the carbon shell to form chemical and structural defects that can act as catalytically active sites or widen the pores of the carbon shell to facilitate the access to the reactants.
(23,27,31,32)
In general, the catalytic activity of an N-doped carbon material is not always proportional to the N content because it can vary depending on the chemical state of N.
(33)
However, the number of structural defects formed by N atoms, which affect the physical pore size, is proportional to the N content. Therefore,
[email protected]
/CNF900 is assumed to have the densest carbon shell because the N content was the smallest. No N was detected in commercial Pt/C before and after heat treatment in an N
2
atmosphere, also supporting that N was mainly derived from aniline in
[email protected]
/CNFs (
Table S2
).

Table 1. XPS Quantitative Results for All Elements of
[email protected]
/CNFs

Figure
2
shows the CV curves of
[email protected]
/CNFs and commercial Pt/C in an Ar-saturated aqueous electrolyte composed of 1 M methanol and 0.1 M HClO
4
. A relatively high methanol oxidation current was obtained with Pt/C, while
[email protected]
/CNFs showed a much lower current: the forward anodic peak current densities were 13.2, 2.4, 1.5, and 1.0 mA cm
–2
for Pt/C,
[email protected]
/CNF600,
[email protected]
/CNF700, and
[email protected]
/CNF900, respectively. This indicates that the carbon shell of
[email protected]
/CNF effectively inhibited methanol from accessing the Pt core. It is also noteworthy that the forward anodic peak current density decreased as the heat treatment temperature increased. The geometric pore size of a perfect graphene is 0.064 nm, which is smaller than the van der Waals radius of helium (0.28 nm).
(34)
Therefore, theoretically, a perfect graphene layer blocks all molecules from passing through. The pore size of the graphene layer can be controlled by forming artificial pores, mostly doping heterogeneous elements such as N. On the same principle, the permeability of methanol was determined by the N content of the carbon shell of
[email protected]
/CNF. As a result,
[email protected]
/CNF900, which showed the highest graphitization degree, most effectively blocked the access of methanol to the Pt core. The anodic current density observed in the backward scan, mainly associated with the oxidation of residual carbon species (intermediates of MOR), was also smaller at
[email protected]
/CNFs than Pt/C because MOR was suppressed at
[email protected]
/CNFs.

div.p:
Figure 2. CV curves of the commercial Pt/C and
[email protected]
/CNFs in 1 M methanol, 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte. The scan rate was 20 mV s
–1
. The inset shows an enlarged image of the −1 to 5 mA cm
–2
current density range.

div.div:
Methanol penetration through the carbon shell of
[email protected]
/CNFs during ORR was assessed by CA.
Figure
3
a–d shows current–time curves of commercial Pt/C and
[email protected]
/CNFs at 0.55 V (vs RHE). Almost zero current density was observed before 500 s because there was no reactant in the electrolyte. Starting to inject O
2
at 500 s, the cathodic current density related to ORR appeared at all samples, indicating that O
2
was able to access the Pt core of
[email protected]
/CNFs, regardless of the heat treatment temperature. The high activity and stability of
[email protected]
/CNFs in ORR was previously reported by our group (
Figure S5
).
(27)
Methanol was then injected after another 1000 s (at 1500 s). For Pt/C, the cathodic current density was significantly decreased by the addition of 1 M methanol due to the competition between ORR and MOR. Anodic current densities were observed when the concentration of methanol was higher than 1 M, indicating that MOR predominated over ORR. A decrease in cathodic current density at
[email protected]
/CNFs was also observed by the addition of methanol. However, no anodic current density was observed for
[email protected]
/CNFs even at a methanol concentration of 5 M. This demonstrates that the carbon shell of
[email protected]
/CNFs played an important role in protecting the Pt core from methanol.
Figure
3
e shows the current densities measured at 1800 s for
[email protected]
/CNFs and commercial Pt/C. The current density shifted in the positive direction for all samples as the concentration of methanol increased. However,
[email protected]
/CNFs showed little change in current density compared to Pt/C. Although the difference in current density was small between
[email protected]
/CNFs,
[email protected]
/CNF900 showed the highest cathodic current density when the concentration of methanol was less than 3 M.
Figure S6
shows the current–time curves of
[email protected]
/CNF900 after the removal of carbon shells. The carbon shell was removed by exposure to the atmosphere at 300 °C for an hour. The removal of carbon shells from
[email protected]
/CNF900 led to a further reduction in cathodic current density compared to the original
[email protected]
/CNF900. This also indicates that the carbon shell inhibited the penetration of methanol. A similar effect was obtained when the support material was carbon black, indicating that the formation of the carbon shell is not affected by the support type (
Figure S7
).

div.p:
Figure 3. Current–time curves of (a) commercial Pt/C, (b)
[email protected]
/CNF600, (c)
[email protected]
/CNF700, and (d)
[email protected]
/CNF900. (e) Current densities measured at 1800 s from (a) to (d). O
2
and methanol began to be injected into the Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte at 500 and 1500 s, respectively.

div.div:
Figure
4
a shows the single-cell polarization curves of
[email protected]
/CNFs as the cathode under 1 M methanol feed.
[email protected]
/CNF900 exhibited the best performance followed by
[email protected]
/CNF600 and then
[email protected]
/CNF700. The current densities measured at 0.4 V were 61, 49, and 177 mA cm
–2
for
[email protected]
/CNF600,
[email protected]
/CNF700, and
[email protected]
/CNF900, respectively. For
[email protected]
/CNF900, the current density (at 0.4 V) of 177 mA cm
–2
was comparable to other reported values in terms of mass activity (
Table S3
).
Figure
4
b shows Nyquist plots of MEAs with
[email protected]
/CNFs. The Nyquist plots were composed of distorted capacitive semicircles and inductive relaxation loops. A curved segment of the negative imaginary plane in the high-frequency region is related to an inductance caused by a conducting wire.
(35)
The high-frequency intercept is the internal resistance of a cell, which is the sum of the electronic and ionic resistances of the cell components. This value was higher for
[email protected]
/CNF heat-treated at a higher temperature. The semicircle in the high-frequency region, mainly attributed to the interfacial impedance between the membrane and catalyst layer, was almost independent of the type of catalyst.
(36)
The diameter of the semicircle in the low-frequency region represents the total charge transfer resistance, which is the sum of the charge transfer resistances of MOR and ORR.
(36,37)
Since the same anode catalyst was used, the difference in total charge transfer resistance was only determined by the cathode catalyst. The total charge transfer resistance was the smallest with
[email protected]
/CNF900 followed by
[email protected]
/CNF600 and
[email protected]
/CNF700, indicating that
[email protected]
/CNF900 was the best cathode catalyst. This result corresponded well with
Figure
4
a. It was reported by our group that
[email protected]
/CNF900 showed the highest ORR activity among
[email protected]
/CNFs (
Figure S5
).
(27)
Therefore, it was supposed that the high ORR activity and methanol tolerance of
[email protected]
/CNF900 resulted in the best single-cell performance.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Single-cell polarization curves and (b) Nyquist plots of
[email protected]
/CNF cathode catalysts at 1 M methanol concentration. The Nyquist plots were recorded at 0.4 V.

div.div:
The high methanol tolerance of
[email protected]
/CNF900 allowed the use of more concentrated methanol as fuel.
Figure
5
a shows the single-cell polarization curves of
[email protected]
/CNF900 at different concentrations of methanol. As the methanol concentration increased from 1 to 5 M, the cell voltage decreased in the low current density region (less than 550 mA cm
–2
), which was related to the kinetics of MOR and ORR. As shown in the Nyquist plots obtained at 0.4 V (
Figure
5
b), the diameter of the semicircle in the low-frequency region increased with the methanol concentration. The increase in the total charge transfer resistance of MOR and ORR may be attributed to the increased degree of catalyst poisoning at both the anode and cathode due to the high methanol concentration. However, in the high current density region (higher than 550 mA cm
–2
), when the methanol concentration was higher than 1 M, the concentration loss was reduced and a higher cell voltage was obtained (
Figure
5
a). The highest maximum current density appeared at a methanol concentration of 3 M rather than 5 M, indicating that the catalyst poisoning and concentration loss reduction by increasing methanol concentration were competitive with each other. The reduction of concentration loss with increasing methanol concentration was observed only for
[email protected]
/CNF900, although the kinetic loss increased.
Figure S8
shows the single-cell polarization curves and Nyquist plots of commercial Pt/C at different methanol concentrations. The cell voltage decreased in all current density regions as the methanol concentration increased. It was also noteworthy that the diameter of the semicircle in the low-frequency region increased dramatically with the methanol concentration. In the case of Pt/C, the degree of catalyst poisoning by the increase of methanol concentration was significantly higher than that of
[email protected]
/CNF900; therefore, no reduction in concentration loss was observed. The improvement in methanol resistance by the carbon shell was also observed when the support was simply changed to carbon black (
Figure S9
). Commercial Pt black, commonly used as the cathode catalyst for DMFC, showed low performance at high methanol concentrations (
Figure S10
).

div.p:
Figure 5. (a) Single-cell polarization curves and (b) Nyquist plots of
[email protected]
/CNF900 at methanol concentrations of 1, 3, and 5 M. The Nyquist plots were recorded at 0.4 V.

div.div:
Figure
6
a,b shows the single-cell polarization curves of
[email protected]
/CNF900 and commercial Pt/C with the number of test cycles, respectively.
[email protected]
/CNF900 outperformed Pt/C over the entire test cycles at the same Pt loading (0.3 mg
Pt
cm
–2
) due to its high ORR catalytic activity (
Figure S5
) and methanol resistance. The high electrical conductivity of CNF would have a positive effect on this result. An initial voltage drop was observed in both commercial Pt/C and
[email protected]
/CNF900 even in the first test cycle, where the methanol crossover did not progress much. This indicates that this voltage drop (activation loss) was largely influenced by the anodic catalysis, not the cathodic catalysis that depends on methanol crossover. The change in cell voltage measured at 100 mA cm
–2
with the number of test cycles is shown in
Figure
6
c. In the first cycle, the cell voltage of
[email protected]
/CNF900 was 0.449 V, and after 200 cycles, it decreased by 8.0% to 0.413 V. On the other hand, the cell voltage of Pt/C decreased by 13.2%, from 0.401 to 0.348 V. It was also notable that the cell voltage of
[email protected]
/CNF900 decreased by 8% over 150 test cycles, whereas in Pt/C, it decreased by 12.5% after only 100 cycles.
[email protected]
/CNF900 also maintained a higher current density than Pt/C for 24 h in a stability test at a cell voltage of 0.5 V, as shown in
Figure S11
. These results support that
[email protected]
/CNF900 showed a higher stability than Pt/C as a cathode catalyst in DMFC.

div.p:
Figure 6. Single-cell polarization curves of (a)
[email protected]
/CNF900 and (b) commercial Pt/C, and (c) cell voltages measured at 100 mA cm
–2
depending on the number of test cycles. The concentration of methanol was 1 M.

div.div:
In DMFCs, the membrane is a very important element in terms of methanol crossover. In general, the thicker the membrane, the lower the methanol crossover rate. However, a thick membrane inevitably increases internal resistance and may degrade overall cell performance. Therefore, to improve DMFC performance, it is desirable to reduce the membrane thickness while minimizing the negative effect of methanol crossover. As part of this effort, the development of cathode catalysts with high methanol tolerance, such as
[email protected]
/CNF900, is underway.
Figure
7
a,b shows the single cell-polarization curves of
[email protected]
/CNF900 and commercial Pt/C with a thinner membrane, Nafion 212 (thickness: 50.8 μm). For both catalysts, the cell performance deteriorated. This is presumed to be because the methanol crossover rate increased by reducing the membrane thickness. However, as shown in
Figure
7
c, the cell voltage measured at 100 mA cm
−2
of
[email protected]
/CNF900 decreased less than that of Pt/C. It decreased by 18.5% and 29.2% for
[email protected]
/CNF900 and Pt/C, respectively. There was no significant improvement in cell performance through the reduction of membrane thickness and the introduction of
[email protected]
/CNF900, but these results confirmed the high methanol tolerance of
[email protected]
/CNF900 again.

div.p:
Figure 7. Single-cell polarization curves of (a)
[email protected]
/CNF900 and (b) commercial Pt/C with Nafion 115 and Nafion 212 membranes, and (c) cell voltages measured at 100 mA cm
–2
depending on the membranes.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this study, Pt–C core–shell catalysts supported on CNFs were synthesized and used as a cathode for DMFC. The synthesized catalysts exhibited higher methanol tolerance than conventional Pt catalysts because the carbon shell effectively protected the Pt core from methanol by selectively permeating oxygen. The selective permeability of the carbon shell increased with the degree of graphitization. Among the synthesized catalysts,
[email protected]
/CNF900, which showed the highest methanol tolerance, performed better than conventional Pt catalysts in single-cell tests under various conditions such as a high methanol concentration and thin membrane.

A review of the exptl. studies on passive and semi-passive direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) is conducted, with an emphasis on high concn. methanol and pure methanol. Key issues such as methanol transport, water management, oxygen transport, and carbon dioxide release in the DMFC are analyzed in detail. The design and fabrication, development approaches, challenges and opportunities on DMFCs passively fed with high concn. methanol are discussed. The advances of DMFC stacks and prototype developments are presented. Several unresolved issues and challenges in DMFCs are identified and reviewed in detail.

This review describes the polymer electrolyte membranes (PEM) that are both under development and commercialized for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC). Unlike the membranes for hydrogen fuelled PEM fuel cells, among which perfluorosulfonic acid based membranes show complete domination, the membranes for DMFC have numerous variations, each has its advantages and disadvantages. No single membrane is emerging as absolutely superior to others. This review outlines the prospects of the currently known membranes for DMFC. The membranes are evaluated according to various properties, including: methanol crossover, proton cond., durability, thermal stability and max. power d. Hydrocarbon and composite fluorinated membranes currently show the most potential for low cost membranes with low methanol permeability and high durability. Some of these membranes are already beginning to impact the portable fuel cell market.

Despite the fact that both electrochem. expts. and d. functional theory calcns. have testified to the superior electrocatalytic activity and CO-poisoning tolerance of PtRu alloy nanoparticles toward the MeOH oxidn. reaction (MOR), the facet-dependent electrocatalytic properties of PtRu nanoparticles are scarcely revealed because it is extremely difficult to synthesize well-defined facets-enclosed PtRu nanocrystals. We, for the 1st time, report a general synthesis of ultrathin PtRu nanocrystals with tunable morphologies (nanowires, nanorods, and nanocubes) through a 1-step solvothermal approach and a systematic study of the structure-directing effects of different surfactants and the formation mechanism by control expts. and time-dependent studies. We use these {100} and {111} facets-enclosed PtRu nanocrystals as model catalysts to evaluate the electrocatalytic characteristics of the MOR on different facets. Remarkably, {111}-terminated PtRu nanowires exhibit much higher stability and electrocatalytic mass activity toward MOR, which are 2.28 and 4.32 times higher than those of {100}-terminated PtRu nanocubes and com. Pt/C, resp., indicating that PtRu {111} facets possess superior MeOH oxidn. activity and CO-poisoning resistance relative to {100} facets. This work provides a series of well-defined PtRu nanocrystals with tunable facets which would be ideal model electrocatalysts for fundamental research in fuel cell electrocatalysis.

A review. Over the past few decades, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have been intensively developed as clean and high-efficiency energy conversion devices. However, their dependence on expensive Pt-based catalysts for both the anode and the cathode make them unsuitable for large-scale commercialization. The essential soln. to addressing this shortfall is the development of low-Pt and non-Pt catalysts. Regarding this issue, considerable advances have been made with low-Pt alloys and core-shell-like catalysts, as well as non-platinum Pd-Me, Ru-Se and heat-treated MeNxCy-based catalysts. This perspective reviews potential pathways for increasing the cost-effectiveness and efficiency of these catalysts. Fundamental understanding of the compn.-activity and structure-activity relationships, innovative synthesis, and promising developmental directions are highlighted. Regarding durability, the main degrdn. mechanism of these catalysts and the corresponding mitigating strategies are presented.

A review. SUMMARY : Direct methanol fuel cells have the potential to power future microelectronic and portable electronic devices because of their high energy d. One of the major obstacles that currently prevent the widespread applications of direct methanol fuel cells is the methanol crossover through the polymer-electrolyte membrane. Methanol crossover is closely related to several factors including membrane structure and morphol., membrane thickness, and fuel cell operating conditions such as temp., pressure, and methanol feed concn. This work presents a comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art technol. for the most important factors, affecting methanol crossover in direct methanol fuel cells. In addn., the current and future directions of the research and development activities, aiming to reduce the methanol crossover are reviewed and discussed in order to improve the performance of direct methanol fuel cells.

A comprehensive review of direct carbon fuel cell technology
Giddey, S.; Badwal, S. P. S.; Kulkarni, A.; Munnings, C.

A review. Fuel cells are under development for a range of applications for transport, stationary and portable power appliances. Fuel cell technol. has advanced to the stage where com. field trials for both transport and stationary applications are in progress. The elec. efficiency typically varies between 40 and 60% for gaseous or liq. fuels. About 30-40% of the energy of the fuel is available as heat, the quality of which varies based on the operating temp. of the fuel cell. The utilization of this heat component to further boost system efficiency is dictated by the application and end-use requirements. Fuel cells utilize either a gaseous or liq. fuel with most using hydrogen or synthetic gas produced by a variety of different means (reforming of natural gas or liquefied petroleum gas, reforming of liq. fuels such as diesel and kerosene, coal or biomass gasification, or hydrogen produced via water splitting/electrolysis). Direct Carbon Fuel Cells (DCFC) utilize solid carbon as the fuel and have historically attracted less investment than other types of gas or liq. fed fuel cells. However, volatility in gas and oil commodity prices and the increasing concern about the environmental impact of burning heavy fossil fuels for power generation has led to DCFCs gaining more attention within the global research community. A DCFC converts the chem. energy in solid carbon directly into electricity through its direct electrochem. oxidn. The fuel utilization can be almost 100% as the fuel feed and product gases are distinct phases and thus can be easily sepd. This is not the case with other fuel cell types for which the fuel utilization within the cell is typically limited to below 85%. The theor. efficiency is also high, around 100%. The combination of these two factors, lead to the projected elec. efficiency of DCFC approaching 80% - approx. twice the efficiency of current generation coal fired power plants, thus leading to a 50% redn. in greenhouse gas emissions. The amt. of CO2 for storage/sequestration is also halved. Moreover, the exit gas is an almost pure CO2 stream, requiring little or no gas sepn. before compression for sequestration. Therefore, the energy and cost penalties to capture the CO2 will also be significantly less than for other technologies. Furthermore, a variety of abundant fuels such as coal, coke, tar, biomass and org. waste can be used. Despite these advantages, the technol. is at an early stage of development requiring solns. to many complex challenges related to materials degrdn., fuel delivery, reaction kinetics, stack fabrication and system design, before it can be considered for commercialization. This paper, following a brief introduction to other fuel cells, reviews in detail the current status of the direct carbon fuel cell technol., recent progress, tech. challenges and discusses the future of the technol.

These results indicate that the PtPdCo/C catalyst is potentially an alternative electrocatalyst for the cathode in DMFCs.

The oxygen-redn. kinetics on Vulcan XC-72 C-supported nanosized Pt-Cr alloy catalysts were studied using the porous rotating disk electrode technique in pure and MeOH-contg. electrolytes. The Vulcan XC-72 C-supported Pt-Cr alloy catalysts with different Pt/Cr at. ratios were prepd. via a Pt-carbonyl route. X-ray diffraction data showed that the as-prepd. nanosized Pt-Cr alloy catalysts mainly have the disordered structures (solid soln.) and that the lattice parameter decreases with the increase in Cr content. Energy-dispersive x-ray anal. indicated that the catalyst compns. are nearly the same as the nominal ones. The obtained Pt-Cr alloy nanoparticles are well dispersed on the surface of C with a relatively narrow size distribution. For example, the mean particle size of the as-prepd. Pt-Cr (1:1)/C catalyst with 20% metal loading is ∼3.1 nm in diam. with a std. deviation of 1.3 nm, and the particle size distribution is relatively narrow. As compared to the Pt/C catalyst, the bimetallic alloy catalysts with the different Pt/Cr at. ratios showed slightly enhanced mass activity (MA) for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR); however, the significant enhancement in the specific activity (SA) by a factor of ∼1.5-3 for the ORR was found on the Pt-Cr alloy catalysts in pure HClO4 soln. This enhancement in SA of the Pt-based catalysts was correlated to the changes in the lattice parameter and Pt/Cr surface compn. Also, the bimetallic Pt-Cr alloy catalysts with the different Pt/Cr at. ratios exhibited much higher MeOH tolerance during the ORR than the Pt/C catalyst. Also, the catalytic activity for MeOH oxidn. on the Pt-Cr alloy catalysts was much lower than that on the Pt/C catalyst. Thus, the high MeOH tolerance of the C-supported Pt-Cr alloy catalysts for the ORR can be ascribed to the weak adsorption of MeOH induced by the presence of Cr atoms in the alloys.

The Pd alloy electrocatalysts were fabricated by a radiofrequency sputtering method. Their electrochem. characteristics for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) were detd. in sulfuric acid soln. with and without methanol at 30 °C. X-ray diffraction anal. shows that Pt-Fe/C catalysts have small cryst. particles and form better Pt-Fe alloy structure with Fe amt. increasing. TEM images evidence that small Pt-Fe nanoparticles homogeneously deposited on carbon support and addn. of Fe can effectively prevent Pt particles agglomeration. Energy-dispersive x-ray anal. and ICP-AES show that Fe precursor cannot be fully reduced and deposited on carbon support through the adopted EG redn. approach. The electrochem. surface area of Pt-Fe/C catalyst obtained through hydrogen desorption areas in the CV curve increases with Fe at. percentage increasing from 0 to ∼50%, and then decreases with more Fe in the Pt-Fe/C catalyst. RDE tests show that the Pt-Fe/C with a Pt:Fe ratio of 1.2:1 and an optimized lattice parameter of around 3.894 Å has the highest mass activity and specific activity to oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). As cathode catalyst, this Pt-Fe/C (Pt:Fe ratio of 1.2:1) exhibits higher direct methanol fuel cell performance at 90° than Pt/C and other Pt-Fe/C catalysts, this could be attributed to its smaller particle size and better Pt-Fe alloy structure.

This work reports on the O redn. activity of several nonprecious metal (non-PGM) catalysts for O redn. reaction (ORR) at the fuel cell cathode, including pyrolyzed CoTPP, FeTPP, H2TMPP, and CoTMPP. Of the studied catalysts, pyrolyzed CoTMPP (Co-tetramethoxyphenylporphyrin) was found to perform significantly better than other materials. The catalyst underwent a thorough testing in both H-air polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEFC) and direct MeOH fuel cell (DMFC). CoTMPP cathode can sustain currents that are only 2-3 times lower than those obtained with a conventional Pt-black cathode in an H2-air PEFC. DMFC expts., including MeOH crossover and MeOH tolerance measurements, indicate high ORR selectivity of the CoTMPP catalyst. Based on results obtained to date, the CoTMPP-based catalyst offers promise for the use in conventional and mixed-reactant DMFCs operating with concd. MeOH feeds. However, H-air fuel cell life data, consisting of over 800 h of continuous cell operation, indicate that improvement to long-term stability of the CoTMPP catalyst will be required to make it practical.

Direct alc. fuel cells (DAFCs) represent the best alternative to batteries for portable and auxiliary power units application due to the high energy d. of short chain alcs. Currently, the utilization of the best platinum group metal (PGM) cathode catalysts is limited, not only by a high cost and scarce resources, but also by the inefficient oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) when permeated alcs. adsorb on the catalytic active sites. In this work, a highly active Fe-N-C catalyst derived from the pyrolysis of nicarbazin (a nitrogen charge transfer org. salt) and an iron precursor has been investigated to get insights on the extraordinary tolerance to the presence of alcs. (methanol and ethanol) of such a PGM-free catalyst. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. demonstrate for the first time that Fe-N4 and Fe-N2C2 active sites preferentially adsorb oxygen with much higher energy than methanol, ethanol and products of partial ethanol oxidn. (0.73-1.16 eV stronger adsorption), while nitrogen-carbon related sites (pyridinic and graphitic nitrogen) are much less selective towards ORR. Half-cell electrochem. characterization showed that the Fe-N-C catalyst overcomes Pt ORR activity in acidic medium with methanol or ethanol concns. as low as 0.01 M. The feasibility of DAFCs operation based on high methanol (up to 17 M) and ethanol (up to 5 M) concn. thanks to the utilization of Fe-N-C cathode catalyst is demonstrated. A new strategy is proposed for DAFCs where using Pt only at the anode and Fe-N-C at the cathode allows extending the device energy d. compared to PGM-based catalysts at both electrodes.

Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) offer great advantages for the supply of power with high efficiency and large energy d. The search for a cost-effective, active, stable and methanol-tolerant catalyst for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) is still a great challenge. In this work, platinum group metal-free (PGM-free) catalysts based on Fe-N-C are investigated in acidic medium. Post-treatment of the catalyst improves the ORR activity compared with previously published PGM-free formulations and shows an excellent tolerance to the presence of methanol. The feasibility for application in DMFC under a wide range of operating conditions is demonstrated, with a max. power d. of approx. 50 mW cm-2 and a negligible methanol crossover effect on the performance. A review of the most recent PGM-free cathode formulations for DMFC indicates that this formulation leads to the highest performance at a low membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) cost. Moreover, a 100 h durability test in DMFC shows suitable applicability, with a similar performance-time behavior compared to common MEAs based on Pt cathodes.

A novel ultrathin carbon layer (UTCL) stabilized Pt catalyst (Pt-UTCL/C) with an open framework is synthesized to significantly enhance the stability of the catalyst in proton exchange membrane fuel cells. Herein, a cheap and widely available polymer, sol. starch (SS) is employed as a precursor to wrap Pt nanoparticles (NPs) and is then carbonized into a UTCL with a thickness of few mol.-layers (0.58 nm on av.) at a mild temp. Significantly, it possesses extremely high stabilities of both electrochem. surface area and ORR compared to the com. Pt/C catalyst even after 10 000 potential cycles. Such excellent stability can be ascribed to the anchoring effect of the UTCL towards Pt NPs to the inhibited migration, agglomeration, and detachment of Pt NPs from the supports as well as to the possibly mitigated dissoln.-growth process of Pt NPs in light of the UTCL.

Nanostructures constituted of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) supported on carbon materials are considered to be among the most active oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) catalysts for fuel cells. However, in practice, the usage of such ORR catalysts is limited by their insufficient durability caused by the low phys. and chem. stability of Pt NPs during the reaction. We herein present a strategy to synthesize highly durable and active electrocatalysts composed of Pt NPs supported on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and covered with an ultrathin layer of graphitic carbon. Such hybrid ORR catalysts were obtained by an interfacial in situ polymer encapsulation-graphitization method, where a glucose-contg. polymer was grown directly on the surface of Pt/CNTs. The thickness of the carbon-coating layer can be precisely tuned between 0.5 nm and several nanometers by simply programming the polymer growth on Pt/CNTs. The resulting Pt/
[email protected]
with a carbon layer thickness of ∼0.8 nm (corresponding to ∼2-3 graphene layers) showed high activity, and excellent durability, with no noticeable activity loss, even after 20 000 cycles of accelerated durability tests. These ultrathin carbon coatings not only act as a protective layer to prevent aggregation of Pt NPs but they also lead to better sample dispersion in solvent which are devoid of aggregates, resulting in a better utilization of Pt. We envision that this polymeric nanoencapsulation strategy is a promising technique for the prodn. of highly active and stable ORR catalysts for fuel cells and metal-air batteries.

Demand on the practical synthetic approach to the high performance electrocatalyst is rapidly increasing for fuel cell commercialization. Here we present a synthesis of highly durable and active intermetallic ordered face-centered tetragonal (fct)-PtFe nanoparticles (NPs) coated with a "dual purpose" N-doped carbon shell. Ordered fct-PtFe NPs with the size of only a few nanometers are obtained by thermal annealing of polydopamine-coated PtFe NPs, and the N-doped carbon shell that is in situ formed from dopamine coating could effectively prevent the coalescence of NPs. This carbon shell also protects the NPs from detachment and agglomeration as well as dissoln. throughout the harsh fuel cell operating conditions. By controlling the thickness of the shell below 1 nm, we achieved excellent protection of the NPs as well as high catalytic activity, as the thin carbon shell is highly permeable for the reactant mols. Our ordered fct-PtFe/C nanocatalyst coated with an N-doped carbon shell shows 11.4 times-higher mass activity and 10.5 times-higher specific activity than com. Pt/C catalyst. Moreover, we accomplished the long-term stability in membrane electrode assembly (MEA) for 100 h without significant activity loss. From in situ XANES, EDS, and first-principles calcns., we confirmed that an ordered fct-PtFe structure is crit. for the long-term stability of our nanocatalyst. This strategy utilizing an N-doped carbon shell for obtaining a small ordered-fct PtFe nanocatalyst as well as protecting the catalyst during fuel cell cycling is expected to open a new simple and effective route for the commercialization of fuel cells.

Systematic Raman studies of nitrogen doped graphene (NG) were conducted. Defective graphene by Ar+ ion bombardment was also studied for comparison. It was found that the defects/nitrogen dopants in NG are not homogeneous. The C-N bonding configuration was found to be pure pyrrolic N, which might be related to the H2 rich growth conditions. The authors' results also suggest that the G peak position and I2D/IG ratio cannot be simply used as fingerprint of doping concn. in NG. Both doping and compressive strain (as verified by transmission electron microscope) contributed to the shift of Raman peaks, while both doping and lattice defects contribute to the attenuation of 2D peak. Finally, the nature of defects in NG was probed and found that they are boundary defects. The detail anal. of the evolution of Raman spectra in NG would greatly help the characterization and future application of this novel material.

Nitrogen-doped carbon (N-C) catalysts can potentially offer high ORR (oxygen redn. reaction) electrocatalytic activity comparable to Pt/C catalysts. Here, we establish a correlation between N-species (pyridinic-N and graphitic-N) with high ORR activity and a key role for Fe in their prepn. N-C catalysts are prepd. from okara (a cheap, nitrogen-rich, biomass precursor) using a facile synthesis method with inclusion of FeCl3 at different steps of synthesis. Mesoporous N-C catalyst is produced that had ORR activity comparable to that of com. Pt/C catalyst. High ORR-activity N-C results from the presence of FeCl3 at a specific step during synthesis. Detailed investigation by XPS reveals that increased levels of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N arose from pyridinic-N-oxide conversion in the presence of Fe. We conclude that transforming inert N species to active N species underlies the increase in active catalytic sites on the carbon surface and offers a means to improve N-C catalyst performance.

It is of great interest to develop metal-free electrocatalysts derived from cheap and environmental friendly biomass for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). Here we report a facile method to prep. graphene-like N-doped carbons with a high degree of graphitization and large surface area using chitosan as precursor and FeCl3 as soft template. The graphitization degree, surface area and the N species can be simply adjusted by controlling the annealing temp. The soft template induced sample annealed at 800 °C (STS800) exhibits more pos. onset potential than the samples annealed at 600 °C and 1000 °C (-0.08 V compared to -0.12 V and -0.15 V), which demonstrates that all of the high degree of graphitization, large surface area and the high percentages of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N play curial roles in the good ORR activity. The value of onset potential for STS800 is just 25 mV neg. than that for Pt/C (-0.08 V to -0.055 V) and the ORR c.d. at merely -0.3 V for STS800 (-2.16 mA cm-2) is larger than that for Pt/C (-2.12 mA cm-2), which indicates its superior ORR activity even compared to Pt/C. Besides, the current for STS800 retains 95% at -0.2 V in 30000 s while that for Pt/C just retains 88%, which reveals its longer durability. With the addn. of 3 M methanol, the CV curve of STS800 shows no noticeable current attenuation, indicating its good methanol tolerance. The excellent ORR activity, good methanol tolerance, and long durability demonstrate that STS800 could be a promising alternative for costly Pt-based electrocatalysts.

Nitrogen-doped carbon materials, including nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) and nitrogen-doped graphene (NG), have attracted increasing attention for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in metal-air batteries and fuel cell applications, due to their optimal properties including excellent electronic cond., 4e- transfer and superb mech. properties. Here, the recent progress of NCNTs- and NG-based catalysts for ORR is reviewed. Firstly, the general prepn. routes of these two N-doped carbon-allotropes are introduced briefly, and then a special emphasis is placed on the developments of both NCNTs and NG as promising metal-free catalysts and/or catalyst support materials for ORR. All these efficient ORR electrocatalysts feature a low cost, high durability and excellent performance, and are thus the key factors in accelerating the widespread commercialization of metal-air battery and fuel cell technologies.

Nitrogen (N)-doped carbon materials exhibit high electrocatalytic activity for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), which is essential for several renewable energy systems. However, the ORR active site (or sites) is unclear, which retards further developments of high-performance catalysts. Here, we characterized the ORR active site by using newly designed graphite (highly oriented pyrolytic graphite) model catalysts with well-defined π conjugation and well-controlled doping of N species. The ORR active site is created by pyridinic N. Carbon dioxide adsorption expts. indicated that pyridinic N also creates Lewis basic sites. The specific activities per pyridinic N in the HOPG model catalysts are comparable with those of N-doped graphene powder catalysts. Thus, the ORR active sites in N-doped carbon materials are carbon atoms with Lewis basicity next to pyridinic N.

This review discusses the genesis of impermeability in graphene and its extraordinary applications in fluid-encasement for wet electron-microscopy, selective gas-permeation, nanopore-bio-diffusion, and barrier coating against rusting and environmental hazards. As the thinnest material, graphene is composed of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms linked to one another in a 2D honeycomb lattice with high electron-d. in its arom. rings, which blocks-off all mols. This phenomena, in combination with its strong structure (C-C bond energy = 4.9 eV and intrinsic strength = 43 N/m) makes graphene the most impermeable membrane (thinnest membrane that is impermeable). Apart from the applications mentioned above, graphene coatings have enabled fundamental studies on chem. processes and fluid structures. For example, graphene can allow electron imaging of nanocrystal nucleation process and water-lattice-structure due to its impermeability. Along with being the strongest, most conductive, and optically-absorbing material (∼2.3% optical absorbance), graphene's impermeability opens a wide range of exciting opportunities.

The processes taking place in direct methanol fuel cell anodes are characterized by a.c. impedance spectroscopy. Under conditions of practical interest, i.e., low methanol stoichiometry factors, the kinetic and the mass-transport resistance give rise to two well-resolved semicircles in the Nyquist plot. When mass transport limitations are excluded, inductive loops occur in the complex plane which are interpreted in terms of the most widely accepted reaction mechanism for methanol electrooxidn. A simple equiv. circuit is used to model this impedance behavior.

The authors report the fabrication of a hierarchical cathode catalyst layer (CL) for application in direct MeOH fuel cells (DMFCs). The hierarchical CL, comprised of Pt black as the inner layer and Pt/C as the outer layer, has appropriate structural properties for DMFC cathode. The inner CL with compact structure decreases the CL thickness and prevent Pt sites from MeOH contamination, and the cathode outer CL with porous structure increase the electrochem. active surface area. Consequently, the hierarchical cathode CL is able to offset the adverse effect of MeOH crossover on the cathode performance by enhancing the Pt catalyst use for O redn. reactions (ORR). Therefore, the newly developed membrane electrode assembly (MEA) can maintain the high ORR activity of the cathode catalysts despite the MeOH crossover. At a high MeOH concn. (3 M), it shows high max. power d. (0.156 W cm-2) despite only 1.0 mg cm-2 of Pt in the cathode CL.

A review of the exptl. studies on passive and semi-passive direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) is conducted, with an emphasis on high concn. methanol and pure methanol. Key issues such as methanol transport, water management, oxygen transport, and carbon dioxide release in the DMFC are analyzed in detail. The design and fabrication, development approaches, challenges and opportunities on DMFCs passively fed with high concn. methanol are discussed. The advances of DMFC stacks and prototype developments are presented. Several unresolved issues and challenges in DMFCs are identified and reviewed in detail.

This review describes the polymer electrolyte membranes (PEM) that are both under development and commercialized for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC). Unlike the membranes for hydrogen fuelled PEM fuel cells, among which perfluorosulfonic acid based membranes show complete domination, the membranes for DMFC have numerous variations, each has its advantages and disadvantages. No single membrane is emerging as absolutely superior to others. This review outlines the prospects of the currently known membranes for DMFC. The membranes are evaluated according to various properties, including: methanol crossover, proton cond., durability, thermal stability and max. power d. Hydrocarbon and composite fluorinated membranes currently show the most potential for low cost membranes with low methanol permeability and high durability. Some of these membranes are already beginning to impact the portable fuel cell market.

Despite the fact that both electrochem. expts. and d. functional theory calcns. have testified to the superior electrocatalytic activity and CO-poisoning tolerance of PtRu alloy nanoparticles toward the MeOH oxidn. reaction (MOR), the facet-dependent electrocatalytic properties of PtRu nanoparticles are scarcely revealed because it is extremely difficult to synthesize well-defined facets-enclosed PtRu nanocrystals. We, for the 1st time, report a general synthesis of ultrathin PtRu nanocrystals with tunable morphologies (nanowires, nanorods, and nanocubes) through a 1-step solvothermal approach and a systematic study of the structure-directing effects of different surfactants and the formation mechanism by control expts. and time-dependent studies. We use these {100} and {111} facets-enclosed PtRu nanocrystals as model catalysts to evaluate the electrocatalytic characteristics of the MOR on different facets. Remarkably, {111}-terminated PtRu nanowires exhibit much higher stability and electrocatalytic mass activity toward MOR, which are 2.28 and 4.32 times higher than those of {100}-terminated PtRu nanocubes and com. Pt/C, resp., indicating that PtRu {111} facets possess superior MeOH oxidn. activity and CO-poisoning resistance relative to {100} facets. This work provides a series of well-defined PtRu nanocrystals with tunable facets which would be ideal model electrocatalysts for fundamental research in fuel cell electrocatalysis.

The carbon-supported Pt and PtRu nanoparticles were activated by thermal treatment to remove the thiol stabilizing shell. Pt52Ru48/C had the best electrocatalytic performance among all carbon-supported Pt and PtRu catalysts.

A review. Over the past few decades, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have been intensively developed as clean and high-efficiency energy conversion devices. However, their dependence on expensive Pt-based catalysts for both the anode and the cathode make them unsuitable for large-scale commercialization. The essential soln. to addressing this shortfall is the development of low-Pt and non-Pt catalysts. Regarding this issue, considerable advances have been made with low-Pt alloys and core-shell-like catalysts, as well as non-platinum Pd-Me, Ru-Se and heat-treated MeNxCy-based catalysts. This perspective reviews potential pathways for increasing the cost-effectiveness and efficiency of these catalysts. Fundamental understanding of the compn.-activity and structure-activity relationships, innovative synthesis, and promising developmental directions are highlighted. Regarding durability, the main degrdn. mechanism of these catalysts and the corresponding mitigating strategies are presented.

A review. SUMMARY : Direct methanol fuel cells have the potential to power future microelectronic and portable electronic devices because of their high energy d. One of the major obstacles that currently prevent the widespread applications of direct methanol fuel cells is the methanol crossover through the polymer-electrolyte membrane. Methanol crossover is closely related to several factors including membrane structure and morphol., membrane thickness, and fuel cell operating conditions such as temp., pressure, and methanol feed concn. This work presents a comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art technol. for the most important factors, affecting methanol crossover in direct methanol fuel cells. In addn., the current and future directions of the research and development activities, aiming to reduce the methanol crossover are reviewed and discussed in order to improve the performance of direct methanol fuel cells.

Giddey, S.; Badwal, S. P. S.; Kulkarni, A.; Munnings, C.

A review. Fuel cells are under development for a range of applications for transport, stationary and portable power appliances. Fuel cell technol. has advanced to the stage where com. field trials for both transport and stationary applications are in progress. The elec. efficiency typically varies between 40 and 60% for gaseous or liq. fuels. About 30-40% of the energy of the fuel is available as heat, the quality of which varies based on the operating temp. of the fuel cell. The utilization of this heat component to further boost system efficiency is dictated by the application and end-use requirements. Fuel cells utilize either a gaseous or liq. fuel with most using hydrogen or synthetic gas produced by a variety of different means (reforming of natural gas or liquefied petroleum gas, reforming of liq. fuels such as diesel and kerosene, coal or biomass gasification, or hydrogen produced via water splitting/electrolysis). Direct Carbon Fuel Cells (DCFC) utilize solid carbon as the fuel and have historically attracted less investment than other types of gas or liq. fed fuel cells. However, volatility in gas and oil commodity prices and the increasing concern about the environmental impact of burning heavy fossil fuels for power generation has led to DCFCs gaining more attention within the global research community. A DCFC converts the chem. energy in solid carbon directly into electricity through its direct electrochem. oxidn. The fuel utilization can be almost 100% as the fuel feed and product gases are distinct phases and thus can be easily sepd. This is not the case with other fuel cell types for which the fuel utilization within the cell is typically limited to below 85%. The theor. efficiency is also high, around 100%. The combination of these two factors, lead to the projected elec. efficiency of DCFC approaching 80% - approx. twice the efficiency of current generation coal fired power plants, thus leading to a 50% redn. in greenhouse gas emissions. The amt. of CO2 for storage/sequestration is also halved. Moreover, the exit gas is an almost pure CO2 stream, requiring little or no gas sepn. before compression for sequestration. Therefore, the energy and cost penalties to capture the CO2 will also be significantly less than for other technologies. Furthermore, a variety of abundant fuels such as coal, coke, tar, biomass and org. waste can be used. Despite these advantages, the technol. is at an early stage of development requiring solns. to many complex challenges related to materials degrdn., fuel delivery, reaction kinetics, stack fabrication and system design, before it can be considered for commercialization. This paper, following a brief introduction to other fuel cells, reviews in detail the current status of the direct carbon fuel cell technol., recent progress, tech. challenges and discusses the future of the technol.

Carbon-supported PtPdCo/C ternary electrocatalysts were prepd. by using the sodium borohydride method for use as a cathode catalyst in direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). The electrocatalyst particles with a size of 2-3 nm were uniformly dispersed on carbon supports. PtPdCo/C showed a similar performance compared to com. Pt/C in the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) tests conducted with a rotating disk electrode (RDE). On the other hand, PtPdCo/C showed higher methanol tolerance than Pt/C in acidic media with methanol. In the single-cell tests, the performance of the PtPdCo/C electrocatalyst was ∼50% higher than that of Pt/C owing to its enhanced methanol tolerance. In the long-term operation test with the single-cell, the max. power d. of PtPdCo/C decreased only by 14% from its initial value. These results indicate that the PtPdCo/C catalyst is potentially an alternative electrocatalyst for the cathode in DMFCs.

The oxygen-redn. kinetics on Vulcan XC-72 C-supported nanosized Pt-Cr alloy catalysts were studied using the porous rotating disk electrode technique in pure and MeOH-contg. electrolytes. The Vulcan XC-72 C-supported Pt-Cr alloy catalysts with different Pt/Cr at. ratios were prepd. via a Pt-carbonyl route. X-ray diffraction data showed that the as-prepd. nanosized Pt-Cr alloy catalysts mainly have the disordered structures (solid soln.) and that the lattice parameter decreases with the increase in Cr content. Energy-dispersive x-ray anal. indicated that the catalyst compns. are nearly the same as the nominal ones. The obtained Pt-Cr alloy nanoparticles are well dispersed on the surface of C with a relatively narrow size distribution. For example, the mean particle size of the as-prepd. Pt-Cr (1:1)/C catalyst with 20% metal loading is ∼3.1 nm in diam. with a std. deviation of 1.3 nm, and the particle size distribution is relatively narrow. As compared to the Pt/C catalyst, the bimetallic alloy catalysts with the different Pt/Cr at. ratios showed slightly enhanced mass activity (MA) for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR); however, the significant enhancement in the specific activity (SA) by a factor of ∼1.5-3 for the ORR was found on the Pt-Cr alloy catalysts in pure HClO4 soln. This enhancement in SA of the Pt-based catalysts was correlated to the changes in the lattice parameter and Pt/Cr surface compn. Also, the bimetallic Pt-Cr alloy catalysts with the different Pt/Cr at. ratios exhibited much higher MeOH tolerance during the ORR than the Pt/C catalyst. Also, the catalytic activity for MeOH oxidn. on the Pt-Cr alloy catalysts was much lower than that on the Pt/C catalyst. Thus, the high MeOH tolerance of the C-supported Pt-Cr alloy catalysts for the ORR can be ascribed to the weak adsorption of MeOH induced by the presence of Cr atoms in the alloys.

X-ray diffraction anal. shows that Pt-Fe/C catalysts have small cryst. particles and form better Pt-Fe alloy structure with Fe amt. increasing. TEM images evidence that small Pt-Fe nanoparticles homogeneously deposited on carbon support and addn. of Fe can effectively prevent Pt particles agglomeration. Energy-dispersive x-ray anal. and ICP-AES show that Fe precursor cannot be fully reduced and deposited on carbon support through the adopted EG redn. approach. The electrochem. surface area of Pt-Fe/C catalyst obtained through hydrogen desorption areas in the CV curve increases with Fe at. percentage increasing from 0 to ∼50%, and then decreases with more Fe in the Pt-Fe/C catalyst. RDE tests show that the Pt-Fe/C with a Pt:Fe ratio of 1.2:1 and an optimized lattice parameter of around 3.894 Å has the highest mass activity and specific activity to oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). As cathode catalyst, this Pt-Fe/C (Pt:Fe ratio of 1.2:1) exhibits higher direct methanol fuel cell performance at 90° than Pt/C and other Pt-Fe/C catalysts, this could be attributed to its smaller particle size and better Pt-Fe alloy structure.

Of the studied catalysts, pyrolyzed CoTMPP (Co-tetramethoxyphenylporphyrin) was found to perform significantly better than other materials. The catalyst underwent a thorough testing in both H-air polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEFC) and direct MeOH fuel cell (DMFC). CoTMPP cathode can sustain currents that are only 2-3 times lower than those obtained with a conventional Pt-black cathode in an H2-air PEFC. DMFC expts., including MeOH crossover and MeOH tolerance measurements, indicate high ORR selectivity of the CoTMPP catalyst. Based on results obtained to date, the CoTMPP-based catalyst offers promise for the use in conventional and mixed-reactant DMFCs operating with concd. MeOH feeds. However, H-air fuel cell life data, consisting of over 800 h of continuous cell operation, indicate that improvement to long-term stability of the CoTMPP catalyst will be required to make it practical.

Direct alc. fuel cells (DAFCs) represent the best alternative to batteries for portable and auxiliary power units application due to the high energy d. of short chain alcs. Currently, the utilization of the best platinum group metal (PGM) cathode catalysts is limited, not only by a high cost and scarce resources, but also by the inefficient oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) when permeated alcs. adsorb on the catalytic active sites. In this work, a highly active Fe-N-C catalyst derived from the pyrolysis of nicarbazin (a nitrogen charge transfer org. salt) and an iron precursor has been investigated to get insights on the extraordinary tolerance to the presence of alcs. (methanol and ethanol) of such a PGM-free catalyst. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. demonstrate for the first time that Fe-N4 and Fe-N2C2 active sites preferentially adsorb oxygen with much higher energy than methanol, ethanol and products of partial ethanol oxidn. (0.73-1.16 eV stronger adsorption), while nitrogen-carbon related sites (pyridinic and graphitic nitrogen) are much less selective towards ORR. Half-cell electrochem. characterization showed that the Fe-N-C catalyst overcomes Pt ORR activity in acidic medium with methanol or ethanol concns. as low as 0.01 M. The feasibility of DAFCs operation based on high methanol (up to 17 M) and ethanol (up to 5 M) concn. thanks to the utilization of Fe-N-C cathode catalyst is demonstrated. A new strategy is proposed for DAFCs where using Pt only at the anode and Fe-N-C at the cathode allows extending the device energy d. compared to PGM-based catalysts at both electrodes.

Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) offer great advantages for the supply of power with high efficiency and large energy d. The search for a cost-effective, active, stable and methanol-tolerant catalyst for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) is still a great challenge. In this work, platinum group metal-free (PGM-free) catalysts based on Fe-N-C are investigated in acidic medium. Post-treatment of the catalyst improves the ORR activity compared with previously published PGM-free formulations and shows an excellent tolerance to the presence of methanol. The feasibility for application in DMFC under a wide range of operating conditions is demonstrated, with a max. power d. of approx. 50 mW cm-2 and a negligible methanol crossover effect on the performance. A review of the most recent PGM-free cathode formulations for DMFC indicates that this formulation leads to the highest performance at a low membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) cost. Moreover, a 100 h durability test in DMFC shows suitable applicability, with a similar performance-time behavior compared to common MEAs based on Pt cathodes.

A novel ultrathin carbon layer (UTCL) stabilized Pt catalyst (Pt-UTCL/C) with an open framework is synthesized to significantly enhance the stability of the catalyst in proton exchange membrane fuel cells. Herein, a cheap and widely available polymer, sol. starch (SS) is employed as a precursor to wrap Pt nanoparticles (NPs) and is then carbonized into a UTCL with a thickness of few mol.-layers (0.58 nm on av.) at a mild temp. Significantly, it possesses extremely high stabilities of both electrochem. surface area and ORR compared to the com. Pt/C catalyst even after 10 000 potential cycles. Such excellent stability can be ascribed to the anchoring effect of the UTCL towards Pt NPs to the inhibited migration, agglomeration, and detachment of Pt NPs from the supports as well as to the possibly mitigated dissoln.-growth process of Pt NPs in light of the UTCL.

Nanostructures constituted of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) supported on carbon materials are considered to be among the most active oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) catalysts for fuel cells. However, in practice, the usage of such ORR catalysts is limited by their insufficient durability caused by the low phys. and chem. stability of Pt NPs during the reaction. We herein present a strategy to synthesize highly durable and active electrocatalysts composed of Pt NPs supported on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and covered with an ultrathin layer of graphitic carbon. Such hybrid ORR catalysts were obtained by an interfacial in situ polymer encapsulation-graphitization method, where a glucose-contg. polymer was grown directly on the surface of Pt/CNTs. The thickness of the carbon-coating layer can be precisely tuned between 0.5 nm and several nanometers by simply programming the polymer growth on Pt/CNTs. The resulting Pt/
[email protected]
with a carbon layer thickness of ∼0.8 nm (corresponding to ∼2-3 graphene layers) showed high activity, and excellent durability, with no noticeable activity loss, even after 20 000 cycles of accelerated durability tests. These ultrathin carbon coatings not only act as a protective layer to prevent aggregation of Pt NPs but they also lead to better sample dispersion in solvent which are devoid of aggregates, resulting in a better utilization of Pt. We envision that this polymeric nanoencapsulation strategy is a promising technique for the prodn. of highly active and stable ORR catalysts for fuel cells and metal-air batteries.

Demand on the practical synthetic approach to the high performance electrocatalyst is rapidly increasing for fuel cell commercialization. Here we present a synthesis of highly durable and active intermetallic ordered face-centered tetragonal (fct)-PtFe nanoparticles (NPs) coated with a "dual purpose" N-doped carbon shell. Ordered fct-PtFe NPs with the size of only a few nanometers are obtained by thermal annealing of polydopamine-coated PtFe NPs, and the N-doped carbon shell that is in situ formed from dopamine coating could effectively prevent the coalescence of NPs. This carbon shell also protects the NPs from detachment and agglomeration as well as dissoln. throughout the harsh fuel cell operating conditions. By controlling the thickness of the shell below 1 nm, we achieved excellent protection of the NPs as well as high catalytic activity, as the thin carbon shell is highly permeable for the reactant mols. Our ordered fct-PtFe/C nanocatalyst coated with an N-doped carbon shell shows 11.4 times-higher mass activity and 10.5 times-higher specific activity than com. Pt/C catalyst. Moreover, we accomplished the long-term stability in membrane electrode assembly (MEA) for 100 h without significant activity loss. From in situ XANES, EDS, and first-principles calcns., we confirmed that an ordered fct-PtFe structure is crit. for the long-term stability of our nanocatalyst. This strategy utilizing an N-doped carbon shell for obtaining a small ordered-fct PtFe nanocatalyst as well as protecting the catalyst during fuel cell cycling is expected to open a new simple and effective route for the commercialization of fuel cells.

Systematic Raman studies of nitrogen doped graphene (NG) were conducted. Defective graphene by Ar+ ion bombardment was also studied for comparison. It was found that the defects/nitrogen dopants in NG are not homogeneous. The C-N bonding configuration was found to be pure pyrrolic N, which might be related to the H2 rich growth conditions. The authors' results also suggest that the G peak position and I2D/IG ratio cannot be simply used as fingerprint of doping concn. in NG. Both doping and compressive strain (as verified by transmission electron microscope) contributed to the shift of Raman peaks, while both doping and lattice defects contribute to the attenuation of 2D peak. Finally, the nature of defects in NG was probed and found that they are boundary defects. The detail anal. of the evolution of Raman spectra in NG would greatly help the characterization and future application of this novel material.

Nitrogen-doped carbon (N-C) catalysts can potentially offer high ORR (oxygen redn. reaction) electrocatalytic activity comparable to Pt/C catalysts. Here, we establish a correlation between N-species (pyridinic-N and graphitic-N) with high ORR activity and a key role for Fe in their prepn. N-C catalysts are prepd. from okara (a cheap, nitrogen-rich, biomass precursor) using a facile synthesis method with inclusion of FeCl3 at different steps of synthesis. Mesoporous N-C catalyst is produced that had ORR activity comparable to that of com. Pt/C catalyst. High ORR-activity N-C results from the presence of FeCl3 at a specific step during synthesis. Detailed investigation by XPS reveals that increased levels of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N arose from pyridinic-N-oxide conversion in the presence of Fe. We conclude that transforming inert N species to active N species underlies the increase in active catalytic sites on the carbon surface and offers a means to improve N-C catalyst performance.
